Genre.name: RPG
Genre.desc: Role-playing games let you assume the role of a protagonist, customizing their abilities, equipment, and appearances. Through exploration, dialogue, and strategic combat, players navigate worlds, uncover lore, complete missions, and level up their characters.

Genre.name: Shooter
Genre.desc: Games in which the player shoots things to progress, usually with a variety of guns, and other times with bows and arrows.

Genre.name: Action
Genre.desc: Featuring fast-paced gameplay, combat mechanics, and challenges that test reflexes and coordination. Often involving physical confrontations, weapon usage, and strategic maneuvers to overcome opponents or obstacles.

Genre.name: Incremental
Genre.desc: A game that has some of or all of the mechanics: Limited interaction or the ability to be played without interaction, rapid growth - often exponential, prestige mechanic(s), An end goal/mission or a general goal of getting a higher amount of currency, and a system of buying and upgrading buildings, units, or similar.

Genre.name: Simulation
Genre.desc: Games that try to simulate real-world activities (like driving vehicles or living the life of someone else) with as much realism as possible. Simulators generally require more study and orientation than arcade games, and the best simulators are also educational.

Genre.name: Roguelike
Genre.desc: Near infinitely replayable games that usually feature, random generation, perma-death, and brutal difficulty.

Genre.name: Platformer
Genre.desc: When jumping over obstacles is one of the main actions, challenges, or mechanics of the game.

Genre.name: Puzzle
Genre.desc: Games that challenge the player with critical thinking to solve levels.

Genre.name: Survival
Genre.desc: Games where the primary goal is keeping the player character alive under harsh circumstances such as dwindling resources or a hostile environment.

Genre.name: Strategy
Genre.desc: Focusing on tactical decision-making, resource management, and long-term planning to achieve victory. Often involving elements like building, defending, and conquering within a structured set of rules and objectives.

Genre.name: Rhythm
Genre.desc: Games that challenges the player's sense of rhythm.

Genre.name: Tabletop
Genre.desc: Games that are normally played on a table or other flat surface, such as board games, card games, dice games, miniature wargames, or tile-based games.

Genre.name: Arcade
Genre.desc: Simple, fast-paced games that require few or no explanations, can be played in short bursts, and usually require a lot of skill.

Genre.name: Sandbox
Genre.desc: A game in which the player is not constrained to achieving specific goals and has a large degree of freedom to explore, interact with, or modify the game environment.

Multiplayer.name: Singleplayer
Multiplayer.desc: The game is pure single player. Server sizes are limited to one player.

Multiplayer.name: Practically Singleplayer
Multiplayer.desc: The gameplay has no interaction with other players yet the server size is more than 1.

Multiplayer.name: Multiplayer
Multiplayer.desc: The gameplay has interactions between players.

Multiplayer.name: PVP
Multiplayer.desc: Player vs. Player. Players compete with each other.

Multiplayer.name: PVE
Multiplayer.desc: Player vs. Environment. Players are against a non-player enemy.

Subgenres/Action.name: MOBA
Subgenres/Action.desc: (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena) two teams of players compete against each other on a predefined battlefield.

Subgenres/Incremental.name: Tycoon
Subgenres/Incremental.desc: Games where the player runs a business with the goal of making as much money as possible.

Subgenres/Incremental.name: Classic Tycoon
Subgenres/Incremental.desc: Games where users get to own a base, usually a business or a company of some kind, and must use “droppers” to earn cash, which can be spent on upgrades to expand the tycoon.

Subgenres/Incremental.name: Clicker
Subgenres/Incremental.desc: A style of game where the player must click on something to earn points, which they spend on upgrades to increase the number of points they earn per click, or to increase the number of points they earn over a period of time without clicking.

Subgenres/Incremental.name: Simulator
Subgenres/Incremental.desc: Games that involve clicking, tapping, or holding repeatedly or going up to a certain object to obtain some type of in-game item to reach a maximum that a player can hold. The in-game item can then be converted into an in-game currency, which can be used to buy improved upgrades to either hold more items or to gain the in-game currency at a faster rate.

Subgenres/Platformer.name: Precision Platformer
Subgenres/Platformer.desc: Platform games with an emphasis on being extremely precise with movements and being extremely challenging.

Subgenres/Platformer.name: Collectathon
Subgenres/Platformer.desc: Games that require you to find and collect items to progress. Each item often require players to complete some sort of challenge.

Subgenres/Survival.name: Open World Survival Craft
Subgenres/Survival.desc: A survival open world game with crafting.

Subgenres/Survival.name: Monsters
Subgenres/Survival.desc: A game where players must survive a monster that is hunting for them.

Subgenres/Survival.name: Disasters
Subgenres/Survival.desc: A game where players must carefully navigate around a map to survive a "disaster."

Subgenres/Strategy.name: RTS
Subgenres/Strategy.desc: A strategy game that is not turn-based.

Subgenres/Strategy.name: TBS
Subgenres/Strategy.desc: A strategy game that is turn-based.

Subgenres/Strategy.name: Tower Defense
Subgenres/Strategy.desc: A type of game where the player builds defensive structures to stop waves of enemies from reaching and destroying their base. Towers can be equipped with many kinds of weapons, but generally are unable to move. Resources earned by defeating enemies allow for more towers to be built.

Subgenres/Tabletop.name: Card Game
Subgenres/Tabletop.desc: Featuring gameplay centered around the strategic use of cards, these games often involve building decks, managing resources, and executing tactical decisions.

Platforms.name: PC
Platforms.desc: This game is playable on PC. Honestly I don't think a single Roblox game isn't playable on PC, so this tag is pretty redundant.

Platforms.name: Mobile
Platforms.desc: This game is playable on mobile devices.

Platforms.name: VR
Platforms.desc: This game is playable in virtual reality.

Platforms.name: Console
Platforms.desc: This game is playable on game consoles such as Xbox.

Game State.name: Alpha
Game State.desc: The game is very early in development. Can have many unfinished aspects.

Game State.name: Beta
Game State.desc: This game is early in development but is generally closer to its end product than not. Often simply testing balancing.

Game State.name: WIP
Game State.desc: This game is not considered finished. Does not include Live Service games.

Game State.name: Abandoned
Game State.desc: This game has ceased development before it could be finished OR is a Live Service game that has stopped receiving updates.

Game State.name: Working
Game State.desc: This game, no matter when it last has received updates, functions as intended.

Game State.name: Broken
Game State.desc: This game does not function as intended.

Game State.name: Finished
Game State.desc: This game is considered finished and now only receives minimal updates or changes.

Game State.name: Live Service
Game State.desc: This game is built around updates. Updates usually change the game in a significant way.

Perspective.name: First Person
Perspective.desc: The game is exclusively played from the point-of-view of the player.

Perspective.name: Third Person
Perspective.desc: The game is exclusively played from a point-of-view over the player's head.

Perspective.name: Top-Down
Perspective.desc: The game is exclusively played from a bird's eye / Top-Down perspective.

Perspective.name: Side Scroller
Perspective.desc: The perspective is always perfectly level and can only move in 2D directions.

Perspective.name: Isometric
Perspective.desc: The camera is in a fixed, isometric position.

Themes.name: Horror
Themes.desc: Games that aim to startle and unnerve the player.

Themes.name: Anime
Themes.desc: Games that feature aspects of Anime.

Themes.name: Exploration
Themes.desc: Games where you discover new locations by traveling around in the game's environment.

Themes.name: Comedic
Themes.desc: Games that attempt to make the player laugh.

Themes.name: Mystery
Themes.desc: Games that contain a mystery to solve.

Themes.name: Meme
Themes.desc: Games that are centered around memes.

Aesthetic.name: Pixel
Aesthetic.desc: Games that have pixelated, 8-bit, 16-bit, low-res, etc visuals

Aesthetic.name: Low-Poly
Aesthetic.desc: Games with models that have low polygon counts.

Aesthetic.name: Colorful
Aesthetic.desc: Games that are colorful and not monochromatic.

Aesthetic.name: Classic Roblox Aesthetic
Aesthetic.desc: Games that purposefully recreate the look and tone of Classic-era Roblox games.

Aesthetic.name: Cute
Aesthetic.desc: Games that are cute and make you go awwww.

Clones.name: Restoration
Clones.desc: This game is a restoration of a game that is either no longer available on Roblox OR is completely broken and left abandoned.
